segment.source: The Windows.UI.Composition API provides the ICompositorInterop, ICompositionDrawingSurfaceInterop, and ICompositionGraphicsDeviceInterop native interoperation interfaces allowing content to be moved directly into the compositor.
segment.target: The Windows.UI.Composition API provides the ICompositorInterop, ICompositionDrawingSurfaceInterop, and ICompositionGraphicsDeviceInterop native interoperation interfaces allowing content to be moved directly into the compositor.

segment.source: Native interoperation is structured around surface objects that are backed by DirectX textures.
segment.target: Native interoperation is structured around surface objects that are backed by DirectX textures.

segment.source: The surfaces are created from a factory object called CompositionGraphicsDevice.
segment.target: The surfaces are created from a factory object called CompositionGraphicsDevice.

segment.source: This object is backed by an underlying Direct2D or Direct3D device object, which it uses to allocate video memory for surfaces.
segment.target: This object is backed by an underlying Direct2D or Direct3D device object, which it uses to allocate video memory for surfaces.

segment.source: The composition API never creates the underlying DirectX device.
segment.target: The composition API never creates the underlying DirectX device.

segment.source: It is the responsibility of the application to create one and pass it to the CompositionGraphicsDevice object.
segment.target: It is the responsibility of the application to create one and pass it to the CompositionGraphicsDevice object.

segment.source: An application may create more than one CompositionGraphicsDevice object at a time, and it may use the same DirectX device as the rendering device for multiple CompositionGraphicsDevice objects.
segment.target: An application may create more than one CompositionGraphicsDevice object at a time, and it may use the same DirectX device as the rendering device for multiple CompositionGraphicsDevice objects.

segment.source: Each CompositionGraphicsDevice serves as a surface factory.
segment.target: Each CompositionGraphicsDevice serves as a surface factory.

segment.source: Each surface is created with an initial size (which may be 0,0), but no valid pixels.
segment.target: Each surface is created with an initial size (which may be 0,0), but no valid pixels.

segment.source: A surface in its initial state may be immediately consumed in a visual tree, for example, via a CompositionSurfaceBrush and a SpriteVisual, but in its initial state the surface has no effect on screen output.
segment.target: A surface in its initial state may be immediately consumed in a visual tree, for example, via a CompositionSurfaceBrush and a SpriteVisual, but in its initial state the surface has no effect on screen output.

segment.source: It is, for all purposes, entirely transparent, even if the specified alpha mode is “opaque”.
segment.target: It is, for all purposes, entirely transparent, even if the specified alpha mode is “opaque”.

segment.source: Occasionally, DirectX devices may be rendered unusable.
segment.target: Occasionally, DirectX devices may be rendered unusable.

segment.source: This may happen, amongst other reasons, if the application passes invalid arguments to certain DirectX APIs, or if the graphics adapter is reset by the system, or if the driver is updated.
segment.target: This may happen, amongst other reasons, if the application passes invalid arguments to certain DirectX APIs, or if the graphics adapter is reset by the system, or if the driver is updated.

segment.source: Direct3D has an API that an application may use to discover, asynchronously, if the device is lost for any reason.
segment.target: Direct3D has an API that an application may use to discover, asynchronously, if the device is lost for any reason.

segment.source: When a DirectX device is lost, the application must discard it, create a new one, and pass it to any CompositionGraphicsDevice objects previously associated with the bad DirectX device.
segment.target: When a DirectX device is lost, the application must discard it, create a new one, and pass it to any CompositionGraphicsDevice objects previously associated with the bad DirectX device.

segment.target: Loading pixels into a surface

segment.source: To load pixels into the surface, the application must call the BeginDraw method, which returns a DirectX interface representing a texture or Direct2D context, depending on what the application requests.
segment.target: To load pixels into the surface, the application must call the BeginDraw method, which returns a DirectX interface representing a texture or Direct2D context, depending on what the application requests.

segment.source: The application must then render or upload pixels into that texture.
segment.target: The application must then render or upload pixels into that texture.

segment.source: When the application is done, it must call the EndDraw method.
segment.target: When the application is done, it must call the EndDraw method.

segment.source: Only at that point are the new pixels available for composition, but they still don't show up on screen until the next time all changes to the visual tree are committed.
segment.target: Only at that point are the new pixels available for composition, but they still don't show up on screen until the next time all changes to the visual tree are committed.

segment.source: If the visual tree is committed before EndDraw is called, then the update that is in progress is not visible on screen and the surface continues to display the contents it had prior to BeginDraw.
segment.target: If the visual tree is committed before EndDraw is called, then the update that is in progress is not visible on screen and the surface continues to display the contents it had prior to BeginDraw.

segment.source: When EndDraw is called, the texture or Direct2D context pointer returned by BeginDraw is invalidated.
segment.target: When EndDraw is called, the texture or Direct2D context pointer returned by BeginDraw is invalidated.

segment.source: An application should never cache that pointer beyond the EndDraw call.
segment.target: An application should never cache that pointer beyond the EndDraw call.

segment.source: The application may only call BeginDraw on one surface at a time, for any given CompositionGraphicsDevice.
segment.target: The application may only call BeginDraw on one surface at a time, for any given CompositionGraphicsDevice.

segment.source: After calling BeginDraw, the application must call EndDraw on that surface before calling BeginDraw on another.
segment.target: After calling BeginDraw, the application must call EndDraw on that surface before calling BeginDraw on another.

segment.source: As the API is agile, the application is responsible for synchronizing these calls if it wishes to perform rendering from multiple worker threads.
segment.target: As the API is agile, the application is responsible for synchronizing these calls if it wishes to perform rendering from multiple worker threads.

segment.source: If an application wants to interrupt rendering one surface and switch to another temporarily, the application may use the SuspendDraw method.
segment.target: If an application wants to interrupt rendering one surface and switch to another temporarily, the application may use the SuspendDraw method.

segment.source: This allows another BeginDraw to succeed, but does not make the first surface update available for on-screen composition.
segment.target: This allows another BeginDraw to succeed, but does not make the first surface update available for on-screen composition.

segment.source: This allows the application to perform multiple updates in a transactional manner.
segment.target: This allows the application to perform multiple updates in a transactional manner.

segment.source: Once a surface is suspended, the application may continue the update by calling the ResumeDraw method, or it may declare that the update is done by calling EndDraw.
segment.target: Once a surface is suspended, the application may continue the update by calling the ResumeDraw method, or it may declare that the update is done by calling EndDraw.

segment.source: This means only one surface can be actively updated at a time for any given CompositionGraphicsDevice.
segment.target: This means only one surface can be actively updated at a time for any given CompositionGraphicsDevice.

segment.source: Each graphics device keeps this state independently of the others, so an application may render to two surfaces simultaneously if they belong to different graphics devices.
segment.target: Each graphics device keeps this state independently of the others, so an application may render to two surfaces simultaneously if they belong to different graphics devices.

segment.source: However, this precludes the video memory for those two surfaces from being pooled together and, as such, is less memory efficient.
segment.target: However, this precludes the video memory for those two surfaces from being pooled together and, as such, is less memory efficient.

segment.source: The BeginDraw, SuspendDraw, ResumeDraw and EndDraw methods return failures if the application performs an incorrect operation (such as passing invalid arguments, or calling BeginDraw on a surface before calling EndDraw on another).
segment.target: The BeginDraw, SuspendDraw, ResumeDraw and EndDraw methods return failures if the application performs an incorrect operation (such as passing invalid arguments, or calling BeginDraw on a surface before calling EndDraw on another).

segment.source: These types of failures represent application bugs and, as such, the expectation is that they are handled with a fail fast.
segment.target: These types of failures represent application bugs and, as such, the expectation is that they are handled with a fail fast.

segment.source: BeginDraw may also return a failure if the underlying DirectX device is lost.
segment.target: BeginDraw may also return a failure if the underlying DirectX device is lost.

segment.source: This failure is not fatal as the application can recreate its DirectX device and try again.
segment.target: This failure is not fatal as the application can recreate its DirectX device and try again.

segment.source: As such, the application is expected to handle device loss by simply skipping rendering.
segment.target: As such, the application is expected to handle device loss by simply skipping rendering.

segment.source: If BeginDraw fails for any reason, the application should also not call EndDraw, as the begin never succeeded in the first place.

segment.source: Scrolling
segment.target: Scrolling

segment.source: For performance reasons, when an application calls BeginDraw the contents of the returned texture are not guaranteed to be the previous contents of the surface.
segment.target: For performance reasons, when an application calls BeginDraw the contents of the returned texture are not guaranteed to be the previous contents of the surface.

segment.source: The application must assume that the contents are random and, as such, the application must ensure that all pixels are touched, either by clearing the surface before rendering or by drawing enough opaque contents to cover the entire updated rectangle.
segment.target: The application must assume that the contents are random and, as such, the application must ensure that all pixels are touched, either by clearing the surface before rendering or by drawing enough opaque contents to cover the entire updated rectangle.

segment.source: This, combined with the fact that the texture pointer is only valid between BeginDraw and EndDraw calls, makes it impossible for the application to copy previous contents out of the surface.
segment.target: This, combined with the fact that the texture pointer is only valid between BeginDraw and EndDraw calls, makes it impossible for the application to copy previous contents out of the surface.

segment.source: For this reason, we offer a Scroll method, which allows the application to perform a same-surface pixel copy.
segment.target: For this reason, we offer a Scroll method, which allows the application to perform a same-surface pixel copy.
